Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: A CEO is generating heat right now for a parental leave fail. I so strongly believe that you don't always have to have a take. It's okay to sit a scandal out. But I *do* have a take because I'm also a mom, a CEO, I'm heading out on mat leave any day now, and I have a lot of team members taking/returning from parental leave. So here are my thoughts with fair warning that this isn't just a "look how awful this company is" screed:1. I don't think the focus on the individual CEO is helpful. This is a broader issue about parental leave in America. And man, do we love to take down a women CEO because any shortcomings she has toward women or parents look especially hypocritical.Have you ever used the phrase "working father?" No, you say he's a lawyer or a CEO or a pilot and then of course he's got kids. But women CEOs are called "working moms" and get all the baggage that comes with having to represent both women and parents in the workplace.2. Parents go through so much and I wish there was more flexibility for all of the heart wrenching situations parents find themselves in, whether it's caring for a sick baby, enduring the devastation of a miscarriage, or going through a fertility journey.It's all so darn hard and while nothing makes it easy, more flexibility and higher salaries help.3. But as a country, we're relying on businesses to provide those resources and (here's the part where I sound like a heartless capitalist) businesses are incentivized to make profits. If we don't have government systems to support parents, we're asking every business to make individual decisions (within the very limited legal protections parents do have) that have really hard tradeoffs.So where I'm at is, yeah, this whole system is pretty nutty. I wish it were better and I wish I knew how to make a bigger difference. But I don't think piling on to an individual's mistake gets us there.

Post Text: Wow. I'll say it. This article *and* the study are bananas. Come with me on this tour of red flags:1. The article describes an experiment where subjects are "shown video of the same start-up business idea presented by a conventionally hot actresses and one who is more plain."Conventionally hot?! Why stop there. How about "smoking hot?" I'm giving this üö©üö©We shouldn't use casually objectifying language in a professional context. Our VP of marketing is effective. Our VP of marketing is not, "rocking a great bod." 2. The article goes on to opine that, "The study does not touch on whether companies founded by attractive women are better investments, however. Maybe it‚Äôs a good strategy?"Wait, we're endorsing this as a strategy?! Here's where I get to üö©üö©üö©Determining capital allocation based on women's attractiveness is not a strategy, unless I guess your fund invests in bets on beauty pageants. 3. But  üö©üö©üö©üö© for the ending. "So maybe the solution is for VC companies is to hire fewer jerks?"No! While I see a lot of jerk behavior in this article, the solution isn't to call people jerks or to hire fewer of them. The solution is to acknowledge there are many biases at play in the workplace and then come up with tactics to ensure decisions aren't made based on those biases.For example, investors can have a standard set of questions they ask all founders, regardless of gender (or hotness?) to fight the tendency that men get asked more about potential than performance. Finally, this article gives the impression that "hot women" easily raise funds: Less than 3% of VC funding goes to all women founding teams.And articles like this don't help us move the needle.

Post Text: "You have to earn a seat at the table" is a controversial piece of advice frequently given to women in male dominated fields and, interestingly, to HR/People Ops.I was thinking about this while on a panel with great People leaders a few weeks back, where we talked about the shift from HR to People Ops.As panelists we thought, whether fair or not, that People Ops often does need to earn a seat at the table because many leaders have worked at companies where HR was just admin.Here's my CEO perspective: leaders often don't know what they're missing out on because they haven't seen great.If you're curious how to show your value, here's an A+ example I've seen Melanie Naranjo do at Ethena:I come to her with a more traditional "HR" ask, like, "Hey, help me hire this role." Melanie could just say, "I'll figure out the comp band and run the logistics on our ATS."Instead, she says things like, "I remember last time we hired for a similar role, we made XYZ mistake because we hadn't thought things through. So I talked with a few people at the company and I learned ABC thing that makes me think we are making the same mistake."And then the key: "My recommendation is we do this next..."She's gotten into the drivers seat versus asking me if she can steer. As a leader, I am so grateful to have someone else helping me solve problems.A great way to "earn" a seat is to literally take it and start showing value right away.#hr #peopleops #leadership #startups

Post Text: Do you do "stay interviews" with your team? In case, like me, you haven't seen these much in your career, stay interviews are interviews you do with your direct reports, especially high performers, to learn what would make them stay or leave.There's a human tendency to fight fires, meaning deal with something when it becomes a mess; but not be proactive.Stay interviews help you proactively manage your talent, versus just scrambling when a A team player shares that they're leaving.As a very recent convert, I now want to evangelize these as a tool for leaders!Much like in a Sales call, the value comes from asking hard/scary questions and then...shutting up! This isn't a "pitch" where you tell your team why they should stay. Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: The most fun thing about running a startup is being wrong. Literally every time we build a new product, I talk with my Ethena team about our hypotheses for how customers will use the product, and every time, we're a little bit wrong.Example:¬†about a month ago, we launched an Anonymous Reporting tool after a deluge of customer requests (thanks to everyone who asked/demanded üòÇ). We thought what our customers wanted was the ability for employees to share concerns and meet regulations like SOC 2, SOX, the EU Whistleblower Directive, etc.But we realized that while companies do need to meet those requirements, the massive pain point, especially in tech is CASE MANAGEMENT. Internally tracking issues, investigations, and resolutions is a problem companies want to fix today.This data often lives in individual emails/brains/scattered docs. And HRBPs have relatively high turnover, so key information leaves with them, and it's hard to spot patterns. üí°üí°üí°Being wrong is fine, IMO. It's the cost of moving quickly. But once we figure out where we are wrong, we need to synthesize customer feedback and keep building in the right direction.Last week, we built an easy flow for HR and Legal to add cases directly in their portal. This fixes the challenge they have with other platforms ‚Äì that it's so painful to add cases that people just won't. So whether you're building a company or taking on a new initiative, embrace being wrong and then be open to the feedback that'll tell you how to make it more right.

Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: These days, my days start with coffee and a read of the latest "DEI is dead" article. Given my general exhaustion with the inevitable trend & backlash cycle, I was thrilled to see Frances Frei, Anne Morriss, and Caroline Elkins's NYT op-ed on DEI. A few points hit home for me:1. If DEI is actually just about the outcome of hiring a person of X background, you both piss everyone off and miss all the gains that come from what is meant to be a process. Not to be all, "it's about the journey, not the destination," but that does seem to be what the research says.For example, the authors cite a study of decision making in drug development where diverse teams performed better *only* when there was psychological safety. This really hit home. I was often the only woman in a military unit and I'd share my perspective at work only when I felt like I wouldn't be mocked for it. Otherwise, I was all, "Yes sir, what a brilliant idea," because what's the point of dissenting when you know it won't matter.2. Diverse is relative to the group that exists. I once heard a joke at a consulting firm that its military consultants were its least diverse "diverse" group. It was both funny and got at an underlying truth ‚Äì¬†you don't often think of a group of mostly white, straight, Christian, conservative men as diverse.But depending on the environment, this can be diversity. The authors cite an example of Harvard Business School's efforts to recruit military students and then a realization that they hadn't set up the internal processes to help these capable students succeed. This is an example of inclusion work even if it doesn't "look" like DEI. Thanks for a more nuanced take on inclusion work ‚Äì my morning ‚òïÔ∏è read was a bit better for it today!

Post Text: This week, I saw a masterclass in how to give unsolicited feedback without being that guy.Someone, let's call him Tim, got me on a call and gave me unsolicited feedback. Surprisingly, this went well!I say surprisingly because if you walked up to me on the playground and said, "Hey, I've been watching you parent and have some pointers," I would react poorly (probably like a feral cat), EVEN IF you had useful things to say.But here's what Tim did really well that I'm going to imitate going forward:1. He asked if I wanted some advice. Now, TBH, this is never totally an ask because it's awkward to say, "no," but it's still a nice opener.2. He did some genuine empathy building. He told me, "I've been in your shoes. Being a CEO is really hard, and you're doing an excellent job at these specific things..."He even said that the thing he was giving me advice on was a problem he himself hadn't totally figured out. What an A+ way to bring down my defenses, versus saying, "Hey, I crushed this thing that you suck at."3. He offered to help. After giving the advice, he shared that he was happy to help make some intros that could help me with the issue. I felt like I wasn't stranded alone with my problem. Sharing in case you find yourself wanting to help someone else with feedback (unless you are on the playground, in which I recommend keeping that to yourself üòÇ). #feedback #feedbackculture

Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: I think the whole "Is Return to Office a war on working moms" debate would be much less of a debate if it was framed, "Is RTO harder for caregivers?"When framed this way, the answer is obvious: Flexibility is key when you're juggling work and caregiving. So yes, mandating where people work is, all things being equal, harder for caregivers than non-caregivers.The pickle is that in the US:1) Women are disproportionately caregivers. "Working mom" is a phrase; "Working dad" is the assumption.2) CEOs are disproportionately men. Women CEOs do finally outnumber CEOs named John in the S&P 500, so hey, there's progress?I'd love to see less tribal and more productive discussions about work but unfortunately, I keep seeing the framing from RTO advocates as, "People with caregiving responsibilities aren't committed to their jobs."That makes it personal because, like many caregivers, I think back to all the moments where I had to be exceptionally hardworking to make this work ‚Äì I literally worked in labor and came back far before my body had healed.I'm not lazy, nor are the many caregivers I work with. We could have more productive discussions about the very real benefits of in-person collaboration if, like I tell my son, we stop the name calling. #rto #workingmom #culture #workculture

Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: A lawyer recently asked me, "How does Ethena compare to the competition when it comes to harassment prevention training?" The short answer is that our DNA is in the gray area. We focus on situations that actually happen, which means we're constantly updating our training to reflect how the workplace changes over time. We used to joke that we're not your mother's sexual harassment prevention training. Honestly, we aren't even the harassment prevention training I took in the Army, which covered mostly absurd, super black and white scenarios. The stuff that made you say, "duh."The issue wasn't just how obvious these scenarios were; it's that traditional training leaves out all the "small stuff" that really compounds.I was just reading our General Counsel, Brandis Anderson's most recent wrap up of important legal developments and came across the EEOC's proposed updates to workplace harassment guidance.It's really encouraging to see that the most recent guidance is in line with Ethena's ethos of, "Let's do more than the bare minimum." The guidance includes a few key takeaways:1. Broad protections for LGBTQ+ colleagues2. The importance of covering pregnancy related decisions3. A focus on virtual, versus in person, harassmentCheck out the blog post for other important developments (including sweeping new requirements in California).

Author: Roxanne Bras Petraeus
Post Text: Last week, I wrote about how when I get really fired up, I try to assume the other person is rational. I imagine the most logical explanation for their actions, which usually causes me to feel less self-righteous and think more clearly. BUT!Literally right after I wrote this post, I had a subway interaction that stretched my imagination.Long story short, 8 months pregnant, I got on a crowded subway car. I found a standing spot but then thought I saw a seated women gesture to sit as she moved her shopping bag onto her lap. Grateful, I plopped down only to have this woman tap me on the shoulder. I removed my headphones assuming she was going to ask when I was due. Instead she said, "I want to know why you choose this seat. There's another seat," and gestured far down the car.Speechless, I slowly put my headphones back on as she said aloud, "That's what I thought! No answer!" and then proceeeded to get off at the next stop.The only saving grace of this interaction was the very New York guy who heckled her on the way out ‚Äì¬†sir, you have my eternal gratitude.I have tried to find a rational explanation for her actions (maybe she didn't notice I was pregnant?!) but have come up short. Yet this interaction notwithstanding, I will still hold onto the "assume the other person is rational" philosophy...and just exclude the subway from this paradigm.
